agoldygirl: Thank you for being so open. Thank you for giving me the courage to share about my own mental health journey. Just today I posted about an anxiety attack that I couldn’t ignore or shake away. I’m learning everyday about myself.
jamieleighbentley: A years and a half ago, we had to make the difficult decision to put my 10yo daughter on antidepressants. She had started becoming consumed by worries and fears to the point she was making herself throw up. And since throwing up was also one of her fears, she wouldn’t eat. My already skinny girl went from 75 lbs to 65 lbs in a week. She cried nearly all day. When she wasn’t crying, she was zoned out on YouTube videos or Fixer Upper. It was heartbreaking to see this goofy, sweet kid suffering like this, and absolutely frightening because of how she was withering away! But as soon as she started tiny like 25mg of Zoloft, the difference was amazing. A little tweaking with the dosage, and it’s like it never even happened. She’s back to being weird, a silly. Anything in life she my get upset by, passes in a matter of minutes. She won’t be on meds forever, but I will always worry about how her anxiety will return if/when it returns. What used to be, “I’m worried I’ll be like this forever,” may change to darker thoughts, which I can’t bear. 💔

kaderon32: Simply want to say Thank You! Thank you for being open, I have been off my meds for a little over a year and I contemplated on whether or not I was going to go back onto them. Last night as I stared up at the night sky begging God not to abandon me I got a serious chill down my back and realized that I might not make it to my 45th birthday, I turn 44 in January. I’m scared that the demons and their havoc that they do on my brain’s chemistry will push me to the edge and I will jump off, or the opportunity to walk in front of a moving vehicle might make the pain and struggle go away or going to sleep and never opening my eyes again will be a permanent cure. So I want to say thank you because even though I know there are so many people with mental illness in the world ; there are fewer people open to share it and talk about it. I’m going Tuesday to get assessed and put back on my meds; I’ve fallen so far down the rabbit hole that I’m trying to claw my way out. But u have given me the courage to see a little light and to take that first step to wanting to live. I don’t want to die, I don’t to feel like my children deserve a better mother and that I’m a screw up.
